He’d always been the picture of health, walking 5 km every morning in Nehru Park, Delhi, and enjoying his evening chai with us. He was 78 yrs old, and heart ailments were the last thing on our minds.
normalised: The day my grandfather, Shiv Kumar, complained of chest pain, our lives took an unexpected turn. He’d always been the picture of health, walking five kilometer every morning in Nehru Park, Delhi, and enjoying his evening chai with us. He was seventy eight years old, and heart ailments were the last thing on our minds.

unnormalised: It started subtly. A tightness in his chest, dismissed as indigestion. Then came the breathlessness after climbing the stairs – attributed to old age. But when the pain became persistent, radiating down his left arm, my mother, a nurse, immediately suspected something was seriously wrong. A quick call to Dr. Rajesh at Max Hospital, Saket, confirmed our fears: a cardiology consult was urgently needed.
normalised: It started subtly. A tightness in his chest, dismissed as indigestion. Then came the breathlessness after climbing the stairs – attributed to old age. But when the pain became persistent, radiating down his left arm, my mother, a nurse, immediately suspected something was seriously wrong. A quick call to Doctor Rajesh at Max Hospital, Saket, confirmed our fears: a cardiology consult was urgently needed.

unnormalised: The next few days were a blur of tests and consultations. An ECG showed abnormalities. An angiogram revealed significant blockages. Dr. Rajesh recommended angioplasty. The procedure, he explained, involved inserting a stent to open up the blocked arteries. My grandfather, a staunch believer in natural remedies, was initially hesitant. He suggested ayurvedic treatment and consultations with Dr. Sharma, an expert in alternative medicine.
normalised: The next few days were a blur of tests and consultations. An E-C-G showed abnormalities. An angiogram revealed significant blockages. Doctor Rajesh recommended angioplasty. The procedure, he explained, involved inserting a stent to open up the blocked arteries. My grandfather, a staunch believer in natural remedies, was initially hesitant. He suggested ayurvedic treatment and consultations with Doctor Sharma, an expert in alternative medicine.

unnormalised: But Dr. Rajesh was firm. He emphasized the severity of the blockages – 90% in one artery, 75% in another. He explained the risk of a heart attack if the procedure was delayed. He patiently answered my grandfather's questions, addressing his concerns about the risks of the procedure and the recovery process. My father, usually the stoic one, was visibly worried, constantly checking his phone for updates from my mother at the hospital.

unnormalised: Finally, convinced by the doctor's expertise and the urgency of the situation, my grandfather agreed. The angioplasty was scheduled for 15/07/2023. The day felt like an eternity. We waited anxiously in the hospital waiting room, praying for everything to go smoothly. My grandmother, normally a pillar of strength, was unusually quiet, clutching her rosary beads.

unnormalised: The procedure, thankfully, was a success. Dr. Rajesh informed us that the stent had been placed successfully, restoring blood flow to the heart. My grandfather spent the next few days in the ICU, monitored closely by the nursing staff. I remember vividly the moment he was moved to a regular room – the relief on my grandmother's face was palpable.
normalised: The procedure, thankfully, was a success. Doctor Rajesh informed us that the stent had been placed successfully, restoring blood flow to the heart. My grandfather spent the next few days in the I-C-U, monitored closely by the nursing staff. I remember vividly the moment he was moved to a regular room – the relief on my grandmother's face was palpable.

unnormalised: The recovery was slow but steady. He had to make significant lifestyle changes: a low-fat diet, regular exercise, and, most importantly, quitting smoking. He started attending cardiac rehab sessions at the hospital and religiously followed Dr. Rajesh's instructions. He was prescribed several medications, including Aspirin 75mg and Atorvastatin 20mg. He even started using a fitness tracker to monitor his heart rate and activity levels.

unnormalised: Now, almost a year later, he’s back to his old self, walking in Nehru Park and enjoying his evening chai. He still complains about the hospital food and the numerous pills he has to take, but we know he is grateful for the medical intervention that saved his life. His health is a testament to the importance of timely medical intervention and the expertise of the cardiology team at Max Hospital. And every time I see him, I'm reminded of the chest pain that started it all and the journey we took together through the world of cardiology. He still visits Dr. Rajesh every 3 months for checkups. He jokes that he's become Dr. Rajesh's most loyal patient.
